Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: A System for Automating End-to-End Creation of Natural Language Interfaces
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to enable more efficient access to information, goods, and services from organizations and businesses through conversational interfaces. With an estimated 33 million voice-activated devices installed in the U.S. by the end of 2017, consumers are beginning to see the benefits of the rise in business services on these devices. Interacting with computers in natural language is more efficient than ever before, and business are urgently seeking to include their services on this new modality. Yet, while advances in machine learning have increased the speed and accuracy with which conversational interfaces are built, today's solutions still result in major bottlenecks in the development process. Addressing these bottlenecks would result in significant savings of time and resources for businesses, in addition to increased convenience for end users.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project advances the development of machine learning and natural language processing technologies that will enable rapid creation of conversational interfaces and increase the efficiency with which individuals interact with computers. Despite major recent advances in conversational interface tooling, current bottlenecks in building robust conversational interfaces still exist, as portions of the development process go from highly-automated to manually-programmed. Instead, the proposed approach will achieve end-to-end automation using an innovative LSTM sequence-to-sequence machine learning model to learn and simulate human behavior on a web page, as well as a new system for open-domain question answering.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project enabled research and development into technology capable of automating the creation of useful commercial applications for voice-enabled devices. Natural language understanding systems have become increasingly commonplace in society, taking the form of virtual personal assistants, automated customer service agents, or voice-enabled speakers. As these voice and chat systems continue to grow in popularity with consumers, businesses are rapidly seeking to include their services on these systems. To do so, Plasticity’s software allows businesses to create their own voice and chat agents with minimal engineering effort by automatically translating their website functionality into a voice- or chat-based agent, saving businesses time and money. Additionally, this provides consumers an interface for more natural and efficient communication with computers, and in turn, the rapid completion of actions.

During this phase, Plasticity built and tested a system that takes in an intent, such as a product search for shoes, and simulates human behavior on a particular website to perform the action and return a result to the end user. Specifically, this project achieved three main goals, which were 1) the construction of a new dataset of 15,000 common sequences of actions taken on websites in order to complete a task, 2) the design and development of a method for simulating human behavior on websites and an open-domain question answering (QA) system, and 3) the technical and commercial feasibility testing of the system. All of these major goals were achieved in Phase I, with additional areas of improvement noted for future phases of development. In addition to these major goals, Plasticity also developed a new crowdsourcing tool for collecting labeled action data on websites and made key accuracy improvements to its state-of-the-art open information extraction API, Plasticity Sapien. Fundamental to Plasticity’s QA system, this open information extraction API now operates with an F1 score of 0.80 on oie-benchmark, topping all open source information extraction technologies available, including ClauseIE, OLLIE, OpenIE-4, PropS, ReVerb, and Stanford CoreNLP.

Between June 2018 and April 2019, Plasticity also tested the commercial feasibility of this technology by speaking with a variety of potential e-commerce customers to understand the frustrations with existing voice and chat solutions. Using Phase I findings, Plasticity is well-equipped to transfer this technology into a publicly accessible, self-service application for the e-commerce, travel, and restaurant verticals, and ultimately power new, useful voice and chat functionality for consumers.


Last Modified: 09/17/2019
Modified by: Ajay Patel

Natural language understanding systems have become increasingly commonplace in society, taking the form of virtual personal assistants, automated customer service agents, or voice-enabled speakers. As these voice and chat systems continue to grow in popularity with consumers, businesses are rapidly seeking to include their services on these systems. To do so, Plasticity?s software allows businesses to create their own voice and chat agents with minimal engineering effort by automatically translating their website functionality into a voice- or chat-based agent, saving businesses time and money. Additionally, this provides consumers an interface for more natural and efficient communication with computers, and in turn, the rapid completion of actions. During this phase, Plasticity built and tested a system that takes in an intent, such as a product search for shoes, and simulates human behavior on a particular website to perform the action and return a result to the end user. Using Phase I findings, Plasticity is well-equipped to transfer this technology into a publicly accessible, self-service application for the e-commerce, travel, and restaurant verticals, and ultimately power new, useful voice and chat functionality for consumers.
